children.subject: Come on, TAs are human too, they can get sick or have other emergencies come up suddenly. Can't you give this guy the benefit of the doubt for this one time?

history.content:
As someone who has been a TA for 2 semester, including for a large class, I believe you are jumping the gun a bit.

Did the TA saying why they were cancelling? As noted by the person below, if they didn't say why, you really don't know what is going on.

You should talk to the professor, make sure they are aware the this TA did that. I agree that it is unprofessional to cancel last minute, but again, benefit of the doubt. Leave that issue to the professor, it is a rare occurrence and is handled case by case.

I also hope that this TA reschedules their OH for another time.

I would like to address your statement of "TAs have an obligation to put the needs of their students above their own".

Simply, they don't.

We are not the department's slaves to you. We are students as well, and the department (and most professors) do well to recognize this, hence why we have hourly appointments.

We are also human. We have limits. We make mistakes. We do our best to support everything going on in our lives, just as everyone else does.

But asking us to ignore our needs to provide for you is a disregard for and a disrespect to us.

Do you have ask us to be at 100% availability 100% of the time, with 100% accuracy? I would hope not.

Yes there are TAs who go above and beyond their work, but it never required, never asked of them. We are a team for a reason, to support and share the work.

I don't know if you've taught before. It's not easy. If you haven't, definitely try it.

I ask that you rethink your position on this. Feel free to talk to any current or former TA.

I hear your frustration.  You wanted help and went to some trouble to get it only to find that it wasn't available.  The way that you phrase your complaint suggests that this

might have happened to you before (perhaps not with the same person, so let's not aim this all at them).  If this is a problem, please do let your instructor and the

department know about it.

That said, I have been a TA (not here...I am not EECS material.  I am the English major you all mock.)  But I taught English 1A/1B a bunch of times as a TA, and there were

times that I got sick.  Or my child got sick.  So please don't feel that the TAs are all in their apartments doing their own homework and ignoring you, because they don't care.

Take care!

Heather

________________________

Thanks, Heather, for this awesome response. To add to this, I would invite OP to email me personally about your experience. I am wondering if this happens frequently? Is this the first time? Does it happen with multiple courses, or just one? We can't help much if we don't know the details! svannostrand@eecs.berkeley.edu

________________________

We are also having a conversation right now, started by OP's concern, about where to give you all a link on the website where you can submit an anonymous form to the CSA, probably to Sarah's wonderful undergrad office in Cory, so the Undergrad Studies and Grad Study Committee can look at any problems that might exist.

I hear your frustration.  You wanted help and went to some trouble to get it only to find that it wasn't available.  The way that you phrase your complaint suggests that this

might have happened to you before (perhaps not with the same person, so let's not aim this all at them).  If this is a problem, please do let your instructor and the

department know about it.

That said, I have been a TA (not here...I am not EECS material.  I am the English major you all mock.)  But I taught English 1A/1B a bunch of times as a TA, and there were

times that I got sick.  Or my child got sick.  So please don't feel that the TAs are all in their apartments doing their own homework and ignoring you, because they don't care.

Take care!

Heather

________________________

children.subject:
None of has defended the TAs who cancelled last minute. None of us condone this. We agree that it is unprofessional and should be brought to attention.

I don't see evidence for the "sheer number" of cancellations, as this has never happened in my experience. Maybe it is different this semester? As the admins note, this should and is being brought to attention, which I appreciate as well.

Yes, I disagree with OPs attitude, with his harshness. I agree with punishment, but OP seems to be missing a point of justice, of understanding where the TA is.

OP did not mention a reasonable excuse, but such excuses can often be personal or private. Again, that is a matter of professionality and goes to the professor.

When I speak of the 100% availability, I refer to OP's demand for putting the students before ourselves, which is IMO a very poisonous attitude toward the teaching staff. We are there to provide support (yes during the expected and scheduled times), but OP did not only refer to the available working hours.

And finally, I refer to teaching, not to address the root of the question, but to welcome OP to see the other side as well.

TL;DR I do NOT condone the TA cancelling unnecessarily. But from what I can telling there is missing information, and judgement should be left to the professor and admins in charge. Bringing it to their attention is the necessary thing to do.
Also sounds  like an exaggeration "sheer number", but then complains about the TA he wanted to go see.

I'm the one who wrote the comment.

Thanks for clarifying some points. I think we had a different interpretation of OP's statement when he said TAs should put prioritize students. Based on the context, I thought he was referring to during OH, since no one really expects anyone to be available 100% of the time. Also, why ask for evidence when you can give "benefit of the doubt"? :P I simply trusted OP, and I don't think there's anything wrong with it.

We may have different opinions, and I'm more than happy to have fruitful discussions. I am just more surprised by how OP is getting bashed on.

To me, he has a perfectly valid reason to bring up a point of discussion--he is suggesting the department to create a new policy that systemically penalizes TAs who may come out as not fulfilling their duties. The current system is no perfect by any means either, so I don't think anything is wrong with having discussions for new policies. Instead, OP is just getting answers like, "deal with it" or "tell the professor". These are just temporary solutions. These don't fix the system. I'm just sad that we are not having more meaningful discussions.

/randomthoughts:

Hm, I think everyone who read this post knows the answer OP wanted to see: people sympathizing with him, and discussing how to improve the system. Maybe it's OP's tone that didn't want to make people help him out...

+1, Although it's hard to sympathize with someone who titles the post "TAs who cancel their office hours should be fired". Improvements to the system can definitely be made, but the best medium is through constructive criticism (which OP's post lacks considerably).

"Telling the professor" may be a temporary solution, but is the most direct and immediate one. It's best to inform upper management so they can communicate the issue to their subordinates. Making a vague Piazza post that obscures specific details doesn't handle the problem directly because the TAs in question don't know OP is talking about them.

I think that responses in this section are harsher in language than OP's suggestion. Sorry I don't mean to put anyone down, but we should not respond to criticism with 10x more criticizing language. We should all use more moderate language, but I feel like OP was really upset at the moment of making the post, and now the intense amount of criticism they have received is making them feel really bad. Ultimately I feel for what OP has to say. I had a similar experience last semester, and I made a post on that class's piazza page about how class organization needs to be improved. There were some responses critical of me for making the post, but most were overwhelmingly positive.
Just goes to show how important it is to know your audience and how you choose your words; best to do it with a clear mind.

Note: I'm not the OP here. I've taught many times before.

I just don't understand why all the responses are defending the TA who canceled last minute.

I see that the OP's phrasing might be a little harsh, but his points are:

1. "SHEER NUMBER" of TAs canceling OH

2. TAs should be fired(penalized) for this

And the responses I see are:

1. TAs are humans, and humans make mistakes.

-> So what? We all know that. We also know that mistakes are bad. If you make one, you should get punished. The OP is simply saying there should be a policy for this.

2. Give benefit of the doubt.

-> Why??? In any case, TAs should provide a reasonable excuse when canceling office hours. The "doubt" part should not exist.

3. TAs are not required to give "100% availability 100% of the time, with 100% accuracy"

-> This is absolutely not what OP said--please don't digress the focus of the discussion. The OP was frustrated at the fact that he could not get help DURING the OH.

4. "I don't know if you've taught before. It's not easy. If you haven't, definitely try it."

-> Simply avoiding the root cause of the question. The OP is just saying be available during working hours. You signed the contract.

All in all, none of the responses provided satisfactory answers to any of OP's points. I'm actually disappointed at the answers.

On a side note, I agree that OP's phrasing was harsh.

I don't know about you but I have never heard an engineering student at Berkeley mock English majors. That is an unfortunate stereotype about EECS/CS majors. Most EECS/CS majors are nice, sociable people... Of course you will always see this stuff on the internet but that isn't representative of the student population.

I hasten to add that if I didn't have tremendous regard for EECS majors, I would not have been working with you all

for as long as I have. Jokes aside.  And if you have any sort of complaint or trouble you can't get addressed around

here, I'm yet another person who would be happy to talk to you and help you find some sort of resolution.

Heather heather@berkeley.edu

From personal experience, it seems to me that most EECS (other engineering, etc) majors would not really do well in a humanities major. People have different skills that make different ways of thinking more or less difficult!

"That said, I have been a TA (not here...I am not EECS material.  I am the English major you all mock.)" I personally find this sentence very sad. While it may be tongue in cheek, it's very unfortunate if humanity majors are actually hurt by the rhetoric or "memes" of EECS majors. I believe every major is precious in themselves and no one should be mocked due to their majors. As a CS major, how can I help to fight against this stance of EECS majors? I hear this a lot but I don't want this to happen.
Shit happens. Maybe you should email the professor instead of complaining on Piazza?

history.content: I know it's midterm week but the sheer number of TAs canceling their office hours, especially during midterm week when students need help the most, is infuriating. Today I walked all the way to Soda expecting a TA to be there only for him to post at the last minute that it would be canceled. Needless to say I was not happy. TAs have an obligation to put the needs of their students above their own; if you have so much trouble balancing the workload of being a TA with your own classes that you need to cancel then please, do not become a TA. Perhaps there should be a policy for professors to penalize TAs who cancel their office hours?
history.subject: TAs who cancel their office hours should be fired
